column2: JAWS can list all links on a webpage in a dialog for quick navigation.
NVDA provides single-letter navigation for headings, links, and form fields in browsers.
VoiceOver on macOS uses the rotor to change navigation modes without opening menus.
JAWS supports application-specific scripts to customize spoken output.
NVDA is open source and allows community-developed add-ons.
Screen readers announce ARIA landmarks such as navigation, main, and complementary regions.
JAWS can read the system tray and running applications from a hotkey.
NVDA can report text formatting like bold and italics when enabled.
VoiceOver can interact with web controls using a virtual cursor separate from the system cursor.
Screen readers can present information through both speech and braille simultaneously.
JAWS supports braille displays for tactile output of on-screen text.
NVDA allows review of the screen independently of the current cursor position.
VoiceOver can read by character, word, line, sentence, or paragraph.
JAWS can announce spelling errors in editable text fields.
NVDA includes a speech viewer for visual monitoring of spoken output.
Screen readers can announce form field labels and required status.
JAWS provides a help system that lists all available commands.
NVDA supports multiple speech synthesizers selectable by the user.
VoiceOver can describe UI controls such as buttons, checkboxes, and sliders.
Screen readers can expose document structure like tables, lists, and headings.
JAWS can track focus changes between windows and dialogs.
NVDA can read mathematical content using MathML support.
VoiceOver can interact with web apps using accessibility APIs.
Screen readers can announce live region updates on dynamic webpages.
JAWS can read PDF documents when they contain tagged text.
NVDA can present object navigation for inspecting UI elements.
VoiceOver supports braille input through connected displays.
Screen readers can announce error messages when form submission fails.
JAWS supports multiple languages through different speech engines.
NVDA can be run from a portable USB drive without installation.
ZoomText provides magnification up to very high levels while preserving text smoothing.
Windows Magnifier offers full-screen, lens, and docked viewing modes.
macOS Zoom allows screen magnification via keyboard shortcuts or trackpad gestures.
High-contrast themes replace interface colors to improve text visibility.
Color inversion swaps light and dark areas to reduce glare for some users.
Cursor enlargement makes the mouse pointer easier to locate on screen.
Focus highlighting visually marks the currently selected control.
Magnification can follow keyboard focus rather than mouse position.
Text-only zoom increases font size without scaling images.
Smooth zoom transitions reduce disorientation compared to abrupt jumps.
Magnifiers can enhance edges to improve object distinction.
Multiple monitor setups can apply different zoom levels per display.
Magnification software can maintain aspect ratio to avoid distortion.
Crosshair overlays help track the center of the magnified area.
Magnifiers can lock onto the caret in text editors.
Some tools provide color filtering for specific vision conditions.
Magnification can be combined with screen reading for dual output.
Lens mode enlarges only a portion of the screen around the pointer.
Docked mode reserves part of the screen for a magnified view.
Zoom can be controlled with keyboard shortcuts for precise scaling.
Magnification can follow text input fields in forms automatically.
Pointer trails improve visibility of fast cursor movement.
Magnifiers can enhance contrast between foreground and background.
Per-app zoom settings allow different magnification for different programs.
Magnification can track the active window instead of the entire desktop.
Screen zoom can be limited to horizontal or vertical directions.
Magnifiers can provide color outlines around UI elements.
Magnification can be used in presentation mode for group viewing.
Some systems allow magnifying touch gestures on trackpads.
Magnifiers can reduce screen clutter by hiding non-essential elements.
Refreshable braille displays use moving pins to form braille characters.
A 40-cell braille display typically shows one line of text at a time.
Braille displays connect to computers via USB or Bluetooth.
Routing keys on braille displays move the cursor to a specific character.
Braille displays present screen reader output in tactile form.
Some braille displays include Perkins-style keyboards for input.
Contracted braille shortens common words using abbreviations.
Uncontracted braille spells out every word letter by letter.
Braille notetakers allow writing and editing without a computer.
Braille displays can pair with smartphones for mobile access.
Braille output enables silent reading in public environments.
Some displays support multiple braille tables for different languages.
Braille devices can navigate text by line, word, or character.
Braille displays can show system notifications tactually.
Braille input allows users to type directly into applications.
Some devices support tactile graphics for simple diagrams.
Braille displays can mirror the screen reader’s review cursor.
Braille users can scroll text using navigation keys on the device.
Braille displays can show formatting indicators such as capitalization.
Some devices include onboard storage for notes and files.
Braille displays can connect to both iOS and Android devices.
Braille output supports proofreading by revealing spelling errors.
Some braille devices include audio output as well as tactile output.
Braille displays can present command prompts and menus.
Braille displays allow line-by-line reading of documents.
Some models are optimized for portability and battery life.
Braille displays can be used in classrooms for accessible learning.
Braille devices can integrate with screen readers like JAWS and NVDA.
Braille displays support navigation of web content.
Braille displays can present cursor position in editable text.
VoiceOver on iOS uses gestures to navigate and activate interface elements.
TalkBack on Android provides spoken feedback for touch interactions.
iOS allows accessibility features to be toggled with a triple-click shortcut.
Android includes an accessibility menu with large on-screen controls.
VoiceOver’s screen curtain turns off the display while keeping audio active.
Braille Screen Input lets users type braille directly on a touchscreen.
VoiceOver announces notifications aloud when enabled.
TalkBack supports reading text by character, word, or line.
VoiceOver’s rotor changes navigation modes such as headings or links.
Android allows custom gestures to be assigned to accessibility actions.
Mobile screen readers announce focused controls and their roles.
VoiceOver can describe images when image descriptions are available.
TalkBack provides spoken hints for performing gestures.
Mobile devices support external braille displays via Bluetooth.
VoiceOver can read text within third-party applications.

Keyboard shortcuts reduce reliance on precise mouse movement.

Focus indicators highlight the active control on screen.
Operating systems allow system font sizes to be increased globally.
On-screen keyboards provide text entry without physical keyboards.
Audio cues can signal when dialogs or alerts appear.
Caret browsing enables text navigation with arrow keys.
Custom shortcut keys automate frequent accessibility actions.
Desktop accessibility includes options for cursor size and color.

Visual alerts can replace system sounds for notifications.

GPS navigation apps provide turn-by-turn audio directions for pedestrians.
Some apps announce nearby intersections and street names.
Indoor navigation systems often rely on Bluetooth beacons.
Audio beacons can mark entrances, elevators, or service desks.

OCR converts images of text into machine-readable characters.
Mobile OCR apps can read printed mail aloud using a phone camera.
Batch scanning allows recognition of multiple pages at once.
OCR accuracy improves with good lighting and flat documents.
Some apps detect document structure such as columns and headings.
Handwriting recognition is less reliable than printed text recognition.
OCR can export recognized text to screen readers.
Language detection allows OCR to read documents in multiple languages.
Skew correction straightens images before recognition.
Cloud-based OCR often provides higher accuracy than offline engines.
OCR can identify text in photographs of signs.
Some OCR tools can recognize currency denominations.
OCR apps can read labels on packaged goods.
Real-time OCR can announce text as the camera moves.
Some apps can detect and read handwritten notes.
OCR can convert scanned PDFs into searchable text.
Text recognition can preserve basic formatting such as paragraphs.
OCR tools can recognize text in multiple fonts.
Some systems provide confidence scores for recognized text.
OCR can export text to braille displays.
OCR apps can read whiteboards or classroom materials.
Some tools can detect orientation and rotate images automatically.

Some apps allow manual correction of recognition errors.
OCR can process business cards into contact information.

OCR can recognize text in multiple scripts.
Some systems can detect text in videos frame by frame.

Some tools provide offline OCR for privacy.
